705772f-a.title: Brooklyn: Montague Street - Clinton Street
705772f-a.text:
Montague Street, south side, between Clinton and Court Streets. At
the extreme right is the U.S. Court, next to it the Academy of Design, and
newt to the last mentioned the Academy of Music. At the left of the Music
Hall, a saloon was openeo in 1860 by Andrew Suydam, later acquired by John M.
Groarty (1881) who also owned the Cceanus House at Rockaway Beach.
1870.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
a76094  NVEG ~ : :
705772f-a.folder: Montague Street & Clinton Street, Brooklyn, NY

705774f-a.title: Brooklyn: Montague Street - Clinton Street
705774f-a.text:
Montague Street, N.E. corner of Clinton Street; a view of the Brooklyn
Trust Co., first of its kind in Brooklyn, established in 1866. At extreme
right, is the National City Bank on Montague Street.
1914.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

703657f-a.title: Brooklyn: Clinton Street - Montague Street
703657f-a.text:
Clinton Street, east side, south from Montague Street.
November 10, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same. a view from the opposite direction. At the W.E.
corner of Remsen and Clinton Streets is seen the Spencer Memorial
Presbyterian Church.
November 10, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

703656f-c.title: Brooklyn: Clinton Street - Montague Street
703656f-c.text:
(1)
Clinton Street, at the N. W. corner of Montague Street,
showing the Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church. The founda-
tion for this edifice,of which Edgar John Barton was the builder,
was begun in August 1844. The chapel opened for services on
June 7, 1846, and the church on April 25, 1847. The steeple, which
was erected in 1860, was removed in 1906. Two buildings (not in
this view) at Nos. 122-124 Pierrepont Street were given to the
parish by George Foster Peabody in 1905 and 1912, to be used as
a guilderhouse and parish house. The rectory was purchased in
1897, and is at No. 126 Pierrepont Street. The church proper
oost t175,000; the spire 275 feet in height, cost an additional
965,000. Minard Lefevre was the architect.
About 1906
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUUCED
(2)
The Montague Street side of the church, viewing east-
ward. The 3y story building on the extreme left is the Trinity
Club.
March 1, 1929
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS
(3)
Another view of the church, vlewing northwestward across
the roof of the Brooklyn Trust Company bu'lding (right foreground).
March 1, 1929
P. L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTD IS

705775f-a.text:
(1)
189-203 Montague Street, north side, between Clinton and Court
Streets. The Montague Street Branch of the Brooklyn Public Library is
seen at No. 197.
February 22, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
NO RCPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, from a different angle.
June 2, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
